#Text=Finnish female politicians highlighted by World Bank 's 2012 gender report
#Text=Sunday , September 29 , 2013
#Text=Earlier this week the World Bank released the 2012 World Development Report on Gender Equality and Development .
#Text=The report noted relatively high numbers of women participating in Finnish politics , and credited the Council for Equality between Men and Women in Finland with progress .
#Text=Pictured in 2003 during a state visit to Brazil , Tarja Halonen was Finland 's first lady President .
#Text=Image : Agência Brasil .
#Text=Finland bucks the global trend ; the report notes globally " the number of women holding parliamentary seats is very low , and progress in the last 15 years has been slow .

#Text=The cross-party Council for Equality between Men and Women in Finland dates back to the 1970s ; the World Bank dismisses its role at that time as  primarily symbolic " with little in the way of staff , funding , or influence .

column1: #Text=In the 1980s it was handed statutory power for gender equality issues and has gone on to press for reforms in areas including sex work , job training , and quotas on political representation .
#Text=The report calls the council a " success " .

#Text=Education , however , showed gender segregation by subject at the tertiary level ; Finland was one of several countries singled out as examples of high gender segregation in economically developed countries , compared to lower levels of segregation in less well-developed nations .
#Text=Finland is one of the four members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development with the highest segregation by subject alongside Croatia , Japan , and Lithuania .
#Text=Finland has very high levels of education enrollment for both boys and girls , at almost 100 % at primary level .
#Text=Females are ahead of men in tertiary education enrollment , with 46 % of men in the relevant age group enrolling in 1991 and 52 % of women .
#Text=By 2009 these numbers stood at 82 % and 101 % respectively .
#Text=Boys and girls were neck and neck with high scores in their 2009 Programme for International Student Assessment maths tests , both averaging around 540 .
#Text=Literacy also produced very high scores but with a gender gap ; boys averaged around 510 while girls averaged around 560 .
#Text=Internet access in Finland is high with men slightly ahead ; for men and women alike access stands at around 85 % .
#Text=Finns have a legal right to a 1Mbps broadband connection and authorities plan to have 100Mbps connections for every citizen by 2015 .
#Text=The proportion of women teleworking at least 25 % of the time has risen from around 7 % in 2000 – 1 to 9 % in 2005 ; the male figure was at 9 % in 2005 and is now 15 – 20 % .
#Text=Rapid teleworking growth is a global trend but the report notes the female figures generally grew faster .
#Text=Marketplace activities also show gender disparity in Finland .
#Text=Of activities performed by men and women , the female share stands at 41 % , versus 63 % for domestic activities such as housework .

#Text=From 2006 – 9 services accounted for 87 % of female and 56 % of male employment . 10 % of women and 37 % of men were employed in industry and agriculture was only a minor employer , with 6 % of male employment and 3 % of female employment .
#Text=Life expectancy for Finnish men has risen from 71 years in 1990 to 77 years in 2009 ; in the same period , women 's life expectancy increased from 79 years to 83 years .
#Text=The population stands at 5 million , representing a 0.4 % annual growth rate from 2000 to 2010 .
